summary: This is an academic review article published in the journal 'Child Abuse Review' in 2015, summarizing research on patterns of disclosure in child sexual abuse, including delays, non-disclosure, and partial disclosure. It discusses findings from various studies and implications for practice. The document is not a primary case file but a research paper cited within the Epstein document set, likely for background or expert context. This is an academic article from the journal 'Child Abuse Review' (2015) titled 'Disclosure Patterns in Child Sexual Abuse'. It reviews research on the complexities of how and when children disclose sexual abuse, focusing on delayed disclosure, barriers, strategies, and implications for legal and therapeutic systems. It cites numerous studies and authors in the field.

persons.name: Rosaleen McElvaney
persons.context: Author of the academic paper and cited researcher who conducted studies on disclosure delays in Ireland.

persons.name: Kogan
persons.context: Author of a 2004 study on disclosure in a national sample of adolescent women, cited for community sample disclosure rates.

persons.name: Smith
persons.context: Researcher (Smith et al., 2000) cited for a study on disclosure patterns among adults who reported childhood rape.

persons.name: Goodman-Brown
persons.context: Lead author of a 2003 model on why children tell about sexual abuse, cited regarding disclosure rates in legal samples.

persons.name: Priebe
persons.context: Researcher (Priebe and Svedin, 2008) cited for a national survey of adolescents in Sweden.

persons.name: Svedin
persons.context: Researcher (Priebe and Svedin, 2008) cited for a national survey of adolescents in Sweden.

persons.name: Hershkowitz
persons.context: Researcher cited for studies on forensic interviews and children's fears about parental reactions to disclosure.

persons.name: Lyon
persons.context: Researcher cited for a 2007 review of studies of children diagnosed with gonorrhoea and their disclosure rates.

persons.name: Lamb
persons.context: Researcher (Lamb et al., 2002) cited for findings on interview protocols that elicit more detail from children.

persons.name: London
persons.context: Researcher (London et al., 2005) cited for noting that disclosure often takes a long time.

persons.name: Olafson
persons.context: Researcher (Olafson and Lederman, 2006) cited regarding the non-representativeness of children whose cases come to court.

persons.name: Lederman
persons.context: Researcher (Olafson and Lederman, 2006) cited regarding the non-representativeness of children whose cases come to court.

persons.name: McElvaney
persons.context: Cited as an author of multiple studies on child sexual abuse disclosure, including a doctoral dissertation and articles on containing the secret of abuse and the 'pressure cooker effect'.

persons.name: Staller
persons.context: Co-author of a 2005 study on disclosure from female survivors of sexual abuse, cited in the article.

persons.name: Nelson-Gardell
persons.context: Co-author of a 2005 study on disclosure from female survivors of sexual abuse, cited in the article.

persons.name: Ungar
persons.context: Cited as lead author on studies (2009a, 2009b) of Canadian youth disclosure strategies and optimal conditions for disclosure.

persons.name: Summit
persons.context: Author of the 1983 'child sexual abuse accommodation syndrome', cited regarding persistent beliefs about why children don't disclose.

persons.name: Quas
persons.context: Co-author of studies on the consequences of legal involvement for child victims (2005, 2011 review).

persons.name: Goodman
persons.context: Co-author with Quas on a 2011 review of consequences of criminal court involvement for child victims.

persons.name: Lalor
persons.context: Co-author with McElvaney on a 2010 review of child sexual abuse links to later exploitation and prevention programs.

persons.name: Jensen
persons.context: Lead author of a 2005 study on children's perspectives on reporting abuse, cited for the dialogical nature of disclosure.

persons.name: Collings
persons.context: Lead author of a 2005 study on patterns of disclosure in child sexual abuse, cited in references.

events.title: Increase in Irish Court Cases
events.description: The 1990s saw a significant increase in complainants in Irish courts reporting childhood sexual abuse, leading to judicial reviews on delayed disclosure.

keyFacts: The paper reviews research consensus that most victims of childhood sexual abuse do not disclose until adulthood, and significant delays are common when disclosure occurs in childhood.
Studies cited show high rates of non-disclosure; for example, 26-28% of participants in large US studies had never disclosed prior to the research survey.
Disclosure patterns are influenced by factors such as the child's age, relationship to the abuser (longer delays for intra-familial abuse), gender (boys more reluctant), and fear of consequences.
Research highlights the importance of being asked direct questions, as many children may not disclose simply because they were not asked.
The article emphasizes implications for legal, child protection, and therapeutic contexts, stressing the need to understand and facilitate the disclosure process.
The article is a scholarly review focusing on the patterns and challenges of disclosure in child sexual abuse cases, not a direct legal document from the Epstein case.
It discusses how delayed and partial disclosure is common and poses challenges for legal investigations and prosecutions.
It cites research indicating many young people disclose first to a peer, and adolescence may be a critical period for disclosure.
The article references Irish legal proceedings in the 1990s where psychological expert testimony was used to explain delays in reporting abuse.
It emphasizes the need for sensitive, non-leading questioning by professionals and the importance of creating opportunities for children to disclose.
